title: 111_hr3737
content:
The "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009" allows intermediaries to report borrower information to credit agencies for credit building. It also provides flexibility in credit terms for small businesses. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS.

Amends the Small Business Act to remove "short-term" from certain paragraphs.

SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require experience in making microloans to startup, newly established, or growing small business concerns for individuals or employees. The Small Business Act now requires experience in providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers as part of a microloan program for startup, newly established, or growing small businesses. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing to $1,000,000 and $7,000,000, with the option to treat it as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate by the Administrator. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance to 35 percent. SEC. 7 introduces the Young Entrepreneurs Program. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program for intermediaries receiving grants to provide technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing small businesses and acquiring financing. The Young Entrepreneurs Program under Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act provides grants to intermediaries to offer technical assistance to individuals aged 25 or younger who have resided in the area for at least 2 years. The Young Entrepreneurs Program provides technical assistance to young entrepreneurs establishing small businesses in the intermediary's geographic area. Repayment on loans received by these entrepreneurs can be deferred for up to 6 months. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE amended to increase loan size from $7,500 to $10,000. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the microloan program. The Administrator must submit a report to the House and Senate Committees on Small Business, detailing the names and locations of intermediaries receiving funds, along with loan and grant amounts provided in each fiscal year. The report required under Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act must include details on the amounts of loans and grants provided to intermediaries, contributions from non-Federal sources, and the number and amounts of microloans made to various groups such as women, low-income individuals, veterans, disabled individuals, and minorities. The report under Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act must detail loans and grants to intermediaries, contributions from non-Federal sources, and microloans to women, low-income individuals, veterans, disabled individuals, and minorities, including marketing and technical assistance provided. The report must include details on loans and grants to intermediaries, contributions from non-Federal sources, microloans to various groups, job creation, repayment history, and business success after receiving microloans. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can provide grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers under this subsection. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 under the Small Business Act, including $80,000,000 in technical assistance grants, $110,000,000 in direct loans, and $10,000,000 in interest assistance grants. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these programs. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS. The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to carry out its provisions. Passed the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009.
